working_definition: Intellectual Disability refers to significantly subaverage general intellectual functioning, existing concurrently with deficits in adaptive behavior, and manifested during the developmental period. These limitations affect a child's educational performance and ability to meet general life demands.

other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.name: Mild Intellectual Disability
other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.definition: Students typically have IQs between 50–70 and can often learn academic skills up to a 6th-grade level with support.

other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.name: Moderate Intellectual Disability
other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.definition: Students may require extensive support for academic and daily living skills and often benefit from functional academic instruction.

other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.name: Severe/Profound Intellectual Disability
other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.definition: Individuals require intensive support across all life areas and benefit from highly individualized instruction focused on basic communication and life skills.

other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.name: Global Developmental Delay
other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.definition: Used for younger children (under age 5) with significant delay in two or more developmental domains, often leading to a diagnosis of intellectual disability later.

common_presentations: Struggles with adaptive behavior or life skills
Difficulty generalizing skills to new settings
Needs support for social interactions and communication

accommodations_modifications.name: Simplified language and concrete examples
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Supports understanding of abstract or complex concepts
accommodations_modifications.example: Teacher uses real-life objects to teach measurement

accommodations_modifications.name: Modified academic curriculum
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Focuses on achievable learning goals tailored to the student's level
accommodations_modifications.example: Student works on a functional math program instead of grade-level content

accommodations_modifications.name: Use of manipulatives and visuals
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Makes abstract ideas concrete and easier to grasp
accommodations_modifications.example: Student uses counters to solve simple addition problems

accommodations_modifications.name: Daily review and overlearning of skills
accommodations_modifications.example: Student practices sight words daily with flashcards

accommodations_modifications.name: Use of graphic organizers and checklists
accommodations_modifications.example: Student uses a step-by-step checklist to complete writing assignments

accommodations_modifications.name: Life skills instruction embedded in daily routines
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: Struggles with adaptive behavior or life skills
accommodations_modifications.example: Student practices grocery shopping role-plays in class

accommodations_modifications.name: Task breakdown into small, manageable steps
accommodations_modifications.example: Teacher breaks math problems into single-step instructions

accommodations_modifications.name: Multiple settings for skill practice
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: Difficulty generalizing skills to new settings
accommodations_modifications.example: Student practices counting at desk and during snack time

accommodations_modifications.name: Extended time for assignments and tests
accommodations_modifications.example: Student receives 50% more time for classroom assessments
